discussion.content:
"You can configure a port as a Layer 2 interface or a Layer 3 interface. A routed interface is a physical port that can route IP traffic to another device. A routed interface is a Layer 3 interface only and does not support Layer 2 protocols, such as the Spanning Tree Protocol (STP).

All Ethernet ports are routed interfaces by default. You can change this default behavior with the CLI setup script."

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/nexus9000/sw/7-x/interfaces/configuration/guide/b_Cisco_Nexus_9000_Series_NX-OS_Interfaces_Configuration_Guide_7x/b_Cisco_Nexus_9000_Series_NX-OS_Interfaces_Configuration_Guide_7x_chapter_0101.html
The answer ". A routed port requires an SVI definition." is wrong because a routed port is ALREADY a layer 3 interface, so it wouldn't require an SVI.

questions.question_text: Which statement is correct regarding a routed port on a multilayer switch?

choices.A: A routed port requires an SVI definition.
choices.D: A routed port is a physical port that supports Layer 3 routing.
choices.C: A maximum of 32 routed ports can be provisioned on a given multilayer switch.
choices.B: Routed ports cannot be configured on a multilayer switch that uses SVIs.

questions.question_text: On a new Cisco Nexus switch, you receive an error message when you attempt to create an SVI. What is the first command you must use to create the SVI?
questions.answer_description: http://docwiki.cisco.com/wiki/Cisco_NX-OS/IOS_Interface_Comparison ==Configuring a Switched Virtual Interface (SVI)== feature interface-vlan interface vlan 10 ip address 192.168.1.1./24 no shutdown

discussion.content: The other three answers are safely eliminated. The 'vlan' command only creates a Layer 2 VLAN, the 'feature svi' command is not a valid command, and the 'interface routed' command creates a physical routed port, not a virtual routed port (SVI).

Technically, you first have to enable to vlan feature. THEN you can configure an SVI:

"Before you can create an SVI in a Nexus switch, you must enable the feature: "

(config)#feature interface-vlan 
(config)#int vlan 3

The link you show is dead, but here's one from the Cisco Press Data Center book that backs up your answer:

https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=URz1DQAAQBAJ&pg=PT950&lpg=PT950&dq=cisco+rebrand+mds&source=bl&ots=ACa80Z6Ftn&sig=ACfU3U15RKeghpMhQ014rREy9k5kBxhWzg&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwiI697HoI3kAhWEalAKHSr2AnUQ6AEwGXoECAkQAQ#v=onepage&q=cisco%20rebrand%20mds&f=false

To summarize from that book:

Formerly known as SAN-OS, starting from release 4.1, it has been rebranded as Cisco MDS 9000 NX-OS software.

questions.answer_description: "While many of the changes leading to convergence are product releases and features, others are more symbolic. One of these symbolic changes is the rebranding, of Cisco MDS 9000 SAN-OS Software as Cisco MDS 9000 NX-OS Software effective with Release 4.1." http://www.cisco.com/en/US/prod/ collateral/ps4159/ps6409/ps5989/ps9898/Rebranding_MDS_90 00.html
questions.question_text: Which version of Cisco Nexus Operating System became a common operating system for Cisco Nexus switches and Cisco MDS storage switches?
What are two core features of Cisco Nexus Operating System? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
System Manager (sysmgr)
 Persistent Storage Service (PSS)

System manager manages processes similar to linux "init".
PSS is a persistent database that any process can write to. 


Another feature that wasn't mentioned is MTS (Message & Transaction Services).

questions.question_text: What are four security features that are included in Cisco Nexus Operating System? (Choose four.)

discussion.content:
You're link is dead. Here's a valid one on Cisco's website that backs up your answers:
